bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert F. Woodward, October 5, 1954

div1.p: Hench states that Finlay and Reed were the two men who made the greatest contribution to mankind in the conquest of yellow fever. Other men only published interesting ideas.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert F. Woodward, October 5, 1954
div1.opener:
October 5, 1954
REF: A.R.A.
Mr. Robert F. Woodward
Acting Assistant Secretary
for Inter-American Affairs
Department of State
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear Mr. Woodward:
div1.p:
I have just returned from Europe and have your letter of September 8
in which you tell me that presumably at an international medical meeting
in Rome in November, a French delegation is planning to present a resolu-
tion to the effect that a French physician (I presume you mean Beauperthy)
was the original discoverer of the mosquito theory of yellow fever.

You ask me “to provide evidence which would support the Cuban assertion,”
that Dr. Carlos Finlay was the first proponent of this theory. I am
quite familiar with this argument and it is distressing to me to see the
contention that still attends this great contribution to mankind. In
essence, there are only two men or two groups that deserve to be men-
tioned seriously in connection with the conquest of yellow fever. They
are Dr. Carlos Finlay who, practically alone, developed the theory that
yellow fever is caused by the Aedes Aegypti mosquito and who, with a
colleague, worked on the theory for 19 years and, second, there is Walter
Walter Reed and his group who, using advanced techniques and so on, were
able to prove the correctness of Doctor Finlay's theory. Before Doctor
Finlay, there were two or three men who put in writing the notion that
perhaps yellow fever might be caused by some agent such as a mosquito
and so on, but these worthy gentlemen were doing nothing more than pub-
lishing an interesting idea. They deserve hardly more than a footnote.

I am a great admirer of Dr. Carlos Finlay and his magnificent work. It
is true that he was not able to present convincing data for various
reasons, one of which was that he had a different purpose (according to
his son) from that of the U.S. Army Commission. I have investigated this
matter over a period of 14 years and have made it my hobby. I have
visited Cuba many times and am preparing a book on the subject. There
are only two things that are holding me up. I still have not obtained
certain important information about Doctor Finlay and there is still a
missing notebook of the Army Commission to find.

I shall be delighted to defend Doctor Finlay's work and there is no real
conflict between the glory that must be his and that which should go to
the Army Commission. These two works stand together and together they
stand alone.

Now precisely what do you want me to do? Without knowing what the French
resolution is to be and not even knowing what French doctor they are re-
ferring to, I am not quite certain what our Cuban friends have in mind in
the way of our help. I note that the convention is to be in November.
Therefore we still have some time and if you will find out from your col-
leagues in the American Embassy in Havana just what they would like to
have me do, I should be glad to do it.

Ten days ago I was in Stockholm for a week at an International Congress
and the Americans were invited to the Embassy. I remembered with pleasure
the luncheon that the ambassador gave for the Kendalls, Mrs. Hench and me
in 1950 and I also remember you with pleasure.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
CONFIDENTIAL ADDENDUM:
Mr. Woodward, it may be that you will want to send the enclosed carbon
copy to Havana and someone there may wish to show it to our Cuban friends.
You are of course aware of the fact that the Cubans have long been vexed
with the proponents of Walter Reed and have tended to be overly
chauvinistic and have refused to see that it was Reed and his colleagues
who proved the veracity of the Finlay theory. Perhaps our Cuban friends
would merely want me to sign my name to a counter resolution they decide
to present. I should be glad to sign it, provided the resolution defends
Finlay properly and not at the expense of the American Commission. I
shall await further instructions.
